data.title: rotation problem when modifying transformation matrix
TextField rendering issue with bgraPacked4444
data.body:
I'm observing TextField rendering issues with the BGRA Packed4444 format.
Windows XP Professional SP3
Only with Internet Explorer 6.0.2900.5512.xpsp.080413-2111 (With Chrome's Pepper it's ok..)
Flash Player 11.9.900.170 (Both with  Debug and Release version)

BGRA Textfield (Rendering correct):
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/1375050/starling_tf_xp_ie6_bgra.png

BGRA Packed 4444 (Render issues):
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/1375050/starling_tf_xp_ie6_bgraPacked4444.png
## 

Solution:
const format:String = "bgra";

data.title: Add rgb and alpha params to RenderTexture's clear() method
data.body: RenderTexture is currently alaways cleared with transparent color (0x000000 and alpha = 0.0), but for some uses it would be more convenient to be able to clear it with a given color and alpha. This is a fairly simple change - two params need to be introduced to the clear() method of RenderTexture (with default values of rgb=0x000000 and alpha=0.0) and passed to RenderSupport's clear() method (which already has such params and default values).

data.title: RenderTexture is missing support for antialiasing
Implied syncing between RenderSupport.blendMode and calls to render QuadBatch(and maybe Quad)

milestone.title: Starling 2.0
milestone.description: This release will come with a much more flexible rendering architecture and some other changes I've been wishing to make for a long time. It won't be compatible with the old releases, though: several APIs will change.

data.body:
So I am raising this as a potential 'gotcha' in code. Maybe you don't want to change how this works, and maybe this implied syncing with the active RenderSupport.blendMode does need to be enforced by developer code externally, but I technically think the way blendMode is passed around when calls to render (and optionally batch) QuadBatch and Quad are unnecessarily tied to the active state of RenderSupport.blendmode when it doesn't have to be.

I came across this peculiarity while trying to use QuadBatches as containers for content in a Sprite but not having them be directly in the DisplayList but just use them in rendering.

A technique you mention a few times in the forums like at:
http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/rendering-issues-w-custom-displayobject
where I was testing a rewrite of the Spine SkeletonSprite to use this QuadBatch technique to separate the creation of cached skeleton QuadBatches only during an update and outside the normal render() calls.

The rub comes along when you might try and build up an array of QuadBatches that you use for rendering (like the internal use of an array of QuadBatches in RenderSupport), as you might have a parent sprite container that needs to hold not just one QuadBatch but an array (checking if state changes required in a more complicated rendering use requires multiple QuadBatches).

The issue is that there are a few places in Starling code where using a QuadBatch which might store its own custom blendMode value is getting ignored by RenderSupport unless you separately also update support.blendMode before calling QuadBatch.render.

For example: in QuadBatch.render() line 454, there is:

``` as3
renderCustom(support.mvpMatrix, alpha * parentAlpha, support.blendMode);
```

so when a QuadBatch is not batchable it is getting its renderCustom() called with the current value of support.blendMode instead of even passing its own potential current custom blendMode.

Now I understand that the default RenderSupport render loop sets the current blendMode off a DisplayObject.blendMode call before rendering it, but given the code above where an explicit QuadBatch is asked to render, doesn't it make more sense to support its direct blendMode value such as using instead:

``` as3
renderCustom(support.mvpMatrix, alpha * parentAlpha, 
    this.blendMode && this.blendMode != BlendMode.AUTO ? this.blendMode : support.blendMode);
```

Additionally, in RenderSupport on both batchQuadBatch() and batchQuad() there is first a check of isStateChange() where one of the comparisons is comparing the QuadBatch(Quad) blendMode against the current support.blendMode to make sure whether there is a state change or not, but then when the actual QuadBatch or Quad gets added, only mBlendMode (RenderSupport) and not the actual blendMode value that is stored in the QuadBatch or Quad is used.

It seems to me the current system essentially forces the proper setting of the active support.blendMode before trying to use QuadBatch or Quads directly during rendering calls, but I think this extra external setting could be avoided if the code just made an attempt of using the blendMode from the QuadBatch or Quad instead of always whatever the current RenderSupport blendMode value is.

So going back to my example where I am using an array of QuadBatches (not in the display list), I can make things work by doing:

``` as3
var numUsedBatches:int  = mCurrentQuadBatchID + 1;
var thisQuadBatch:QuadBatch;
for (var i:int=0; i<numUsedBatches; ++i) {
    thisQuadBatch = mQuadBatches[i];
    support.blendMode = thisQuadBatch.blendMode;
    thisQuadBatch.render(support, alpha);
}
```

but I would think the extra call to make sure I set the active support.blendMode is just a workaround because calling QuadBatch.render() isn't doing this for me automatically?

Maybe this isn't a big issue for most custom rendering code now, but I wonder if it could be something that trips people up in the future.

Thanks

data.title: Sprite zero dimension children affect bounds
data.body:
While this is not a big issue, and is easy to circumvent programmatically, it can cause issues for new developers.

If we have a sprite with zero-dimensions sprite or quad as a child at (x,y), the bounds() method considers (x,y) to be within the area to include in the bounds analysis, even if no actual active pixels are present.

data.title: Starling.dispose() Error
data.body:
After call Starling.dispose(); - runtime error from Flash Bulder FP 11.8 OS Win7 x64.

Error: Error #3694: The object was disposed by an earlier call of dispose() on it.
    at flash.display3D::Context3D/createVertexBuffer()
    at starling.display::QuadBatch/createBuffers()[\src\starling\display\QuadBatch.as:174]
    at starling.display::QuadBatch/set capacity()[\src\starling\display\QuadBatch.as:643]
    at starling.display::QuadBatch/expand()[\src\starling\display\QuadBatch.as:160]
    at starling.display::QuadBatch/addQuad()[\src\starling\display\QuadBatch.as:284]
    at starling.core::RenderSupport/batchQuad()[\src\starling\core\RenderSupport.as:334]
    at starling.display::Image/render()[\src\starling\display\Image.as:184]
    at starling.display::DisplayObjectContainer/render()[\src\starling\display\DisplayObjectContainer.as:351]
    at starling.display::Sprite/render()[\src\starling\display\Sprite.as:230]
    at starling.display::DisplayObjectContainer/render()[\src\starling\display\DisplayObjectContainer.as:351]
    at starling.display::Sprite/render()[\src\starling\display\Sprite.as:230]
    at starling.display::DisplayObjectContainer/render()[\src\starling\display\DisplayObjectContainer.as:351]
    at starling.core::Starling/render()[\src\starling\core\Starling.as:416]
    at starling.core::Starling/nextFrame()[\src\starling\core\Starling.as:371]
    at starling.core::Starling/onEnterFrame()[\src\starling\core\Starling.as:574]

What wrong?

data.title: TextField error
data.body: Flash running in the browser. When reducing the page, fonts in the text box increases.

data.title: FragmentFilter changes and new Bloom Filter
data.body:
I've created a BloomFilter (like the fog filter in Pixelmator); basically a gaussian blur on a new layer, blended with the lighten mode.

To allow this I've had to make some changes to the FragmentFilter.  One (changing the protection on calculateBounds) is optional but useful if you ever need to do size calculations in a FragmentFilter subclass.

The other is to allow rendering to a filter, rather than the backbuffer; see here for an alternative solution http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/mist-or-glow-filter

Overall I think this is a better solution as its more de-coupled.  In addition don't thing the (removed) assertion is valid -  Stage3D is quite happy to render AGAL programs to textures.

I think this also resolves #391 (its a bloom filter :); although I'd echo the comments there on making it easier to extend FragmentFilter as, although it's not a major issue given this implementation, it was a pain in the ass while trying other solutions.

data.title: TextField onRestore can get called when mTextBounds is null?
data.body:
Daniel, wanted to just post this for you to check when you have time.

Given the conversations on this post:
http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/statsdisplay-textfield-bug-error-3605-sampler-0-binds-an-invalid-texture

There is a question on whether some users can see the onRestore of a TextField called possibly before a render, leading to a null exception on mTextBounds.

Not sure if you can confirm, or want to add that new null check code inside the  onRestore function for mTextBounds as a defensive measure.

Thanks

data.title: Flattened Sprite with TextField loses texture when text changes.
data.body: I have Sprite with TextField added to it. This Sprite contains more than one object, so I use flatten(). When text on that TextField changes, and I dont use flatten() again, Starling throws "Error #3663: Sampler 0 binds an undefined texture". Expected result is that changes on that text are not visible until flatten(), or Starling should throw more understandable error.

data.title: Preferred to use RectTexture
Juggler.delayCall doesn't receive same parameters as new DelayedCall
data.body:
If we compare both functions we can see there is a difference in the third argument passed:

```
Juggler.delayCall(call:Function, delay:Number, ...args):DelayedCall
```

vs

```
public function DelayedCall(call:Function, delay:Number, args:Array=null)
```

as you can see, the first one recieves "...args" while the second one receives "args:Array"

This always gave me the same error if I used delayCall instead of new DelayedCall:

```
[Fault] exception, information=TypeError: Error #1034: Type Coercion failed: cannot convert []@64ff121 to Function.
```

It's an easy fix ;)

data.title: Update TouchEvent#getTouch() and TouchEvent#getTouches()
data.body: Update TouchEvent#getTouch() and TouchEvent#getTouches() to use event.currentTarget by default. Because that is what we usually use.

data.title: Method get hasVisibleArea() in DisplayObject
BitmapFonts not loading
data.body:
I just got the latest version of Starling although I am not sure what version I am replacing.

All of the BitmapFonts in my project have stopped working.  They worked fine prior to updating Starling.  The project does not throw any errors, the text is just missing.

data.title: Starling stage scaling problems
add Texture and Texture atlas pivot
ClipRect and pivot
data.body:
If we have a sprite with some images in there and we set the clipRect for instance a half of its size everything is good. ClipRect is set properly and if we move some of his children that are out of this "viewPort" to the clipping area then it is drawn proprly also.

The problem is with pivots of the clipped sprite. 
If we animate the pivots properties of an clipped sprite then nothig out of this clipping area that moves to the clipping are is rendered.

Don't know if it is a bug of possible limitation of the clipping implementation :)

data.title: Juggler/Tween works on only one object
data.body:
Hi,

new Tween() and Juggler.animate takes only 1 object!
what if we want to pass an array of objects that will use same animation properties.

using a loop or multiple tween objects seems bad to me.

Thanks

data.title: Added background and backgroundColor simple support to TextField
"Event.ADDED_TO_STAGE" just dispatch one times
Why using private attributes when you could use protected ?
data.body:
You're using private attributes in many places, such as core.Starling.
It prevent anyone that likes your framework but want to tweak some behavior to override them with simple inheritance.

Right now, if one would want to tweak something, one would need to copy paste your full code, or to edit directly your framework, both would make any future evolution/maintenance difficult.

Why not moving all those private to protected ?

data.title: Allow options injection for more flexibility.
Enable ColorMatrixFilter function chaining
data.body:
This allows, e.g.:

```
new ColorMatrixFilter()
    .adjustHue(h)
    .adjustSaturation(s)
    .adjustBrightness(b);
```

data.title: AssetManager issues with multiple starling instances
data.body:
I am working on a desktop application that requires displaying content on multiple monitors/displays. 

Multiple starling instances works, however asset management with the assetManger is not possible. There seems to be a problem with the loading of assets to the right starling instance. 

It seems like the assetManager is loading to the current starling instance instead of the starling instance of the nativeWindow that owns it. 

related link: 
the following link covers the same problem, in case I missed anything in my explination. 
http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/multiple-assetmanagers-with-multiple-starling-instances#post-49571
